results.title: Acquiring a taste for Raffaella
results.creator_credit: Sandra Lepore, Fotini Manikakis and AFTRS
results.brief_description: The onset of menstruation leads to a curious mix of events when Raffaella shares the news with her traditional Italian Aunt. Together they make some special Italian love biscuits, “biscotti di amore”, with a secret ingredient intimately linked with Raffaella’s menarche. When the object of her affections tastes the love biscuits, surprisingly, he asks for the recipe.

results.title: In the name of the crow
results.creator_credit: Marion Benjamin, Mark Bin Bakar, Peter Kordyl, Robert Bropho, Heather Williams and Excalibur Nominees
results.brief_description: Most tourists who visit Rottnest Island are unaware of its history. Established as a prison for Aboriginal men around 1840, it was intended as a place for “rehabilitation”. However, accounts of floggings, chainings and hangings flourished on the mainland despite official enquiries and commissions suggesting everything was in order. In this documentary, Robert Bropho takes us to the island and traces the hardship and the suffering of his ancestors that has been omitted from white man’s history.

results.title: Boomalli: five Koorie artists
results.creator_credit: Michael Riley, Paul Humfress and Film Australia
results.brief_description: Boomalli is an artists’ co-operative - a collection of photographers, painters, sculptors, designers and filmmakers, who are urban Aboriginal or Koorie artists. The work presented ranges from that of fashion designer Bronwyn Bancroft, the sand sculpture of Fiona Foley, Tracey Moffatt’s film, “Nice coloured girls” and the paintings of Raymond Meeks and Jeffrey Samuals. This visually rich and inspiring film is about their work. Their achievements speak for themselves.

results.title: Cass: no saucepan diver
results.creator_credit: Wayne Barker and Australian Institute of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Studies
results.brief_description: In 1982 Aboriginal filmmaker Wayne Barker returned to his home in Broome, Western Australia to make a film about his grandfather, Cass Drummond. The result is this personal portrait of a staunchly self-reliant old man as he looks back on his life in the pearling industry and comments on what it was like to be an Aboriginal earlier this century.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Wayne Barker and Australian Institute of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Studies

results.title: Two bob mermaid
results.creator_credit: Darlene Johnson, Antonia Barnard and Core Films
results.brief_description: In this visually stunning short film set in the 1950s, a fair-skinned Aboriginal girl gains access to the local swimming pool where Aboriginal people are legally denied access (Source: Australian Screen)

results.title: Round up
results.brief_description: Round Up follows the journey of two country boys who find themselves out of place in the hustle and bustle of the big city. Here in this unfamiliar environment, they may learn that they are not as different as they first thought.
results.description: Round Up follows the journey of two country boys who find themselves out of place in the hustle and bustle of the big city. Here in this unfamiliar environment, they may learn that they are not as different as they first thought.

results.title: Journey (Sen)
results.brief_description: A young boy leaves his isolated home town hitching across a forever changing landscape. His travels cause him to relive fragments of the life left behind as he struggles to find rest in a journey that may never end. An award winning short from Indigenous filmmaker Ivan Sen whose other films include Tears, Wind and Dust.

results.title: Dust (On Wheels )
results.brief_description:
Two groups of teenagers - a white brother and sister, and two Aboriginal mates - come together to find work on a dusty cotton field in the outback. What they discover hidden in the ground, is history itself. Switching effortlessly from the naturalism of the relationships between the youth to the grandeur of the mythic power and terror of the resolution, this short film is an exemplary example of contemporary Australian cinema.
Mick is young, white and angry at the world. His sister Amy is trying to keep it all together, not an easy task when Mick seems determined to screw things up. Leroy is afraid his future holds nothing beyond this life in the mirage of a dusty field. His best mate Vance works alongside him, more interested in Amy than chipping weeds. Ruby, Leroy’s mother is the only one who notices when the uneasy sky forces the elements to merge. As a violent dust storm awakes, racial differences must be put aside as the five shelter in Leroy’s car. Australia’s history, black and white, is revealed as the storm unearths the secrets that lie beneath the surface of the land.
